content.text: Bash pwd Command - Print Working Directory
The pwd command shows you the full path of the folder you're currently in.
content.html: The pwd command shows you the full path of the folder you're currently in.

content.text: To see the full path of the current folder, just type pwd :
content.html: To see the full path of the current folder, just type pwd:

content.code_html:
pwd
/home/user/my_directory

content.text: The pwd command supports a few options to customize its output:
content.html: The pwd command supports a few options to customize its output:

content.text: The -L option shows the logical path, including any symbolic links.
content.html: The -L option shows the logical path, including any symbolic links.

content.text: This is the default behavior of pwd .
content.html: This is the default behavior of pwd.

content.code_html:
pwd -L
/home/user/my_directory

content.text: The -P option shows the physical path, resolving any symbolic links to their actual locations.
content.html: The -P option shows the physical path, resolving any symbolic links to their actual locations.

content.text: This is useful when you need to know the exact physical directory structure.
content.html: This is useful when you need to know the exact physical directory structure.

content.code_html: pwd -P

content.text: Why Knowing Your Current Directory is Important
Knowing which folder you're in is important when moving around the filesystem. It helps you make sure you're in the right place when running commands that use relative paths.
content.html: Knowing which folder you're in is important when moving around the filesystem. It helps you make sure you're in the right place when running commands that use relative paths.
